The CO2 transfer hydrogenation with bio-glycerol over a Ni-zeolite was systematically studied to produce formic and lactic acids. The alkaline hydrothermal reactions without a catalyst and with Ni-zeolite heterogeneous catalyst were explored, focusing on the effects of base types and concentrations, reaction atmosphere and temperature. In alkaline hydrothermal reactions without catalyst, NaOH demonstrated superior performance at 1 M. A Ni/NaZSM-5 catalyst showed astounding performance giving 9.3 mol-L−1-g−1 lactic acid and 6.5 mol-L−1-g−1 formic acid at 250 °C after 2 h. Notably, the zeolite showed resistance to the highly basic conditions of the reaction medium. For the first time, CO2 conversion in aqueous phase was reported addressing the complexity of CO2 solubility. A reaction network was proposed including the diverse glycerol transformations not yet studied for this system. Overall, this study sheds light on the understanding of this complex reaction system and the potential of Ni-supported zeolites for sustainable CO2 utilisation. Amongst the various CO2 utilisation alternatives, conversion into fuels and chemicals appears to be the most effective for the abatement of CO2 emissions, with the potential to contribute to a reduction of 15 Gt of CO2 per year [1,2]. In line with this, the most widely investigated route to transform CO2 into fuels and chemicals is via hydrogenation [3–6], implying the consumption of large amounts of hydrogen. Traditionally, hydrogen has been obtained from fossil fuels, but life cycle assessments on CO2 hydrogenations have shown that significant improvements could be achieved in terms of global warming impact if non-fossil derived hydrogen is used instead [3,7]. In this regard, one promising avenue could be the hydrogenation of CO2 using liquid organic H-donors by the process of transfer hydrogenation (H-transfer). H-transfer has been mostly applied to the upgrading of biomass-derived feedstocks to fuels and valuable chemicals [8–10]. It uses organic molecules, such as alcohols and organic acids, which act as H-donors, facilitating the reduction reaction in the aqueous phase [11]. The process is environmentally benign and safer than traditional hydrogenations, as it does not require pyrophoric reducing agents, can proceed at relatively low temperature (50–250 °C), and does not require pressurised H2 gas [12]. Therefore, the application of H-transfer reactions to the conversion of CO2 into fuels and chemicals has recently been gaining research momentum as a novel, more sustainable alternative method for CO2 valorisation [13–26]. Aqueous phase hydrogen transfer (APHT) of CO2 was first reported by the Peris group [27] in 2010, where the reduction of CO2 with isopropanol (iPrOH) was achieved using a molecular iridium (Ir) catalyst with N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands under alkaline hydrothermal conditions. Using KOH as a base promoter, turnover numbers (TON) up to 150 were obtained for formate, the corresponding salt of formic acid. Since then, research has expanded in this area with the majority of reports employing Ir and ruthenium (Ru) molecular catalyst systems for the reduction of CO2 and CO2-derived carbonate salts with various alcohol reductants including iPrOH, glycerol and ethanol (EtOH). Systems using gaseous CO2 typically report CO2 pressures of up to 50 bar and mild temperatures ranging from 110 to 200 °C [13,17,18,28]. In all cases, alkaline hydrothermal conditions (0.5–1 M KOH) were employed. Ikariya and coworkers reported a turnover frequency (TOF) of 131 for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formate with iPrOH using a C-N chelating Cp*Ir complex [19]. Reactions were performed with atmospheric pressure CO2 at 80 °C with 1 M KOH. Systems using carbonate salts have proven to give much higher yields compared to gaseous CO2 feedstocks. For example, the Beller group reported on the reduction of HCO3 – with MeOH as H-donor using Ru pincer complexes at 150 °C in 0.6 M KOH [15]. In this case, the hydrogenation product was reported as formate, giving 33 % yield (1300 TOF) after 4 h and a yield of 92 % after 36 h. The choice of H-donor is, in fact, an important design aspect for the process. Employing biomass-derived chemical waste streams as H-donors could promote a circular chemical industry, reducing waste and increasing economic value. In line with this, glycerol could be a very appealing H-donor given its low environmental impact, high availability, and low cost when compared to other H-donors (e.g. 2-propanol, tetralin or formic acid) [12]. Global production of glycerol is projected to be 6.3 Mt in 2025 with approximately 64 % coming from the biodiesel industry [29], currently exceeding market demands [30]. In addition, glycerol is already a versatile raw material for producing many valuable chemicals, polymers and fuels [31]. One such chemical is lactic acid (LA), which can be produced via glycerol dehydrogenation. LA finds applications in the cosmetic, food, and textile industries, but it is also used in the synthesis of polylactic acid (PLA), a biodegradable bioplastic [32]. LA is typically produced by glycerol fermentation, but hydrothermal conversion of glycerol has recently emerged as an alternative to fermentation and could help valorise bio-glycerol. Glycerol hydrothermal conversion is a base catalysed reaction where alkali earth metal hydroxides, typically NaOH, are employed [31,33]. Base has been identified to drive several steps of the reaction pathway ( Scheme 1). First it is needed for the initial dehydrogenation of glycerol to a glyceroxide ion intermediate. It also drives the conversion of glyceraldehyde intermediate to 2-hydroxypropenal, as well as the final transformation of a pyruvaldehyde intermediate to lactic acid via benzylic acid rearrangement [32,34]. In the presence of high temperature water (up to 300 °C), glycerol can also be initially transformed into a 1-hydroxyacetone intermediate and further reacted to pyruvaldehyde [35]. Over metallic catalysts, the pyruvaldehyde intermediate is instead transformed to hydroxyacetone and, with acid catalysts, propylene glycol is obtained as the final product [36–39]. Furthermore, the improvement of glycerol valorisation routes would further increase the value and attractiveness of biodiesel production. When considering CO2/carbonate APHT with glycerol, thermodynamic calculations reveal the conversion to LA and formic acid (FA) as the desired route [14]. The calculations show that production of LA is 21.5 kcal mol−1 more favourable than that of dihydroxyacetone when H-transfer is considered. Additionally, despite presenting a more complex reaction network than iPrOH, glycerol is seen to be thermodynamically more favourable as H-donor, producing various value-added chemicals. The first report of glycerol as H-donor for CO2 APHT was in 2011 by Aresta and coworkers [16]. A Ru-triphenylphosphine molecular catalyst was successful in the transformation of gaseous CO2 to formic acid and glycerol to glycolic acid. Since then, reports have emerged with astounding success in the transformation of CO2 or carbonates to FA and glycerol to LA [14,40,41]. An Ir-abnormal NHC catalyst was employed for bubbling of CO2 through aqueous glycerol at atmospheric pressure to afford a TOF of 149 for FA [18]. Reactions were performed at 150 °C with 1 M K2CO3. The highest yields to date were reported by Jang and coworkers [42] who used an Ir-NHC complex at 200 °C reaction temperature. TOFs in excess of 10,000 and 20,000 for formate and lactate respectively were achieved when employing K2CO3 as carbon source. Most studies in literature on CO2 APHT refer to the use of homogeneous catalysts. However, developing this process with heterogeneous catalysts overcomes the challenges of regeneration and recovery that accompanies homogeneous catalyst systems. Ease of separation, recycling and economical reactor design are all advantages to heterogeneous catalysis. Only few reports applying heterogeneous catalytic procedures to CO2/carbonates APHT have been reported [20–23,25,43–45], with some protocols also having demonstrated great efficiency. Lin and coworkers [44] tested various metallic catalysts on activated carbon (AC) supports for the APHT of NaHCO3 with glycerol and reported catalyst activity in the order Pd > Rh > Pt > Ru ≫ Ni. The highest yield of products observed with the 5 wt% Pd/AC catalyst were 55 % and 29 % for lactate and formate respectively, with 81 % glycerol conversion. Reactions conditions were 1 M glycerol and 1 M NaHCO3, for 12 hours in subcritical water at 240 °C under 28 bar N2 and with 0.1 g catalyst. AC was also superior to metal oxide, sulfate and carbonate supports. This superior performance was attributed to the unique effects of AC properties on the morphology of the Pd nanoparticles and good diffusion of the aqueous reactants in the support. Most recently, PdPt nanoparticles supported on N-doped carbon spheres with wrinkled cages (NCSWCs) were employed by Dong et al. [23] with Na2CO3 acting as both base and CO2 source. Excellent results were achieved with maximum glycerol conversion of 93 % and acid yields of 77 % LA and 67 % FA over Pd2Pt1/NCSWCs at 200˚C after 10 h reaction time. The study revealed the importance of tuning the catalyst d band centre to optimise the adsorption and dissociation energies of adsorbed H species on the catalyst surface. Base-free CO2 APHT was also attempted by Deng et al. [20]. CO2 hydrogenation to formaldehyde was achieved using a 0.5 wt% Ru/LDH (layered double hydroxide) catalyst. The highest yield of formaldehyde was found to be 462 mmol L−1 g−1 under the conditions where 50 mg of catalyst was used in 0.2 M aqueous glycerol, 10 bar CO2 at 50 °C, and 12 h reaction time. However, glycerol conversions of only 11 % with LA yield of 35 mmol L−1 g−1 were achieved. The highest glycerol conversions, up to 46 %, occurred when Na2CO3 was used instead of CO2. Under these conditions, formaldehyde and LA yields were 405 and 107 mmol L−1 g−1 respectively. In the search to develop cheap, robust and highly active heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 APHT with glycerol, the dual functionality of glycerol dehydrogenation and CO2 activation/hydrogenation must be considered. Ni is a popular and well-studied metal for catalysing hydrogenation reactions [46], even more so for CO2 hydrogenation to methane [47]. It has also shown promising results in the hydrothermal conversion of glycerol in both mono- and bimetallic catalytic systems [48]. Encouragingly, Ni has shown good activity in the APHT of glycerol with unsaturated compounds including cyclohexene, benzene and levulinic acid [49]. In the optimised system, a bimetallic 10 %Ni-10 %Co/CeO2 catalyst showed excellent activity for the reduction of 1-decene, giving glycerol conversions up to 92 % and yields of LA and the saturated product (decane) of 91 % and 85 %, respectively. Though the bimetallic system was found to be most active, monometallic tests concluded that Ni had higher intrinsic activity for the dehydrogenation of glycerol than Co. Moreover, Ni is a significantly cheaper alternative to noble metals (e.g. Pt and Pd). Combining Ni with zeolites could be, in fact, of particular interest for use in CO2 APHT reactions. Besides the well-known unique characteristics of zeolites, including high surface area, molecular-sized pores, ability to stabilize metal species, ability to tailor acid-base character, etc., [50–52] Ni supported zeolites have been proven to be highly active in traditional CO2 hydrogenation to methane [53–61]. Bacariza et al. reported excellent activity using 15 wt% Ni-based USY (ultra-stable Y) [62], BEA, MOR and ZSM-5 [63] measuring conversions of ≥ 65 % and selectivities ≥ 95 %. Key factors in the success of the catalysts included the use of alkaline earth metals as compensating cation to boost support basicity, higher Si/Al ratio linked to improved hydrophobicity, and improved metal dispersion. On the other hand, while zeolites have been widely explored for glycerol conversions such as hydrogenolysis to propylene glycol [64–71], they have been less so for glycerol hydrothermal conversion to lactic acid. A couple of these studies focused on the base-free catalytic selective oxidation using noble metal catalysts supported on acidic zeolites [72,73]. Success of these catalysts was attributed to superior water resistance and acidity of the zeolite supports. On the other hand, De Andrade et al. [39] found that in the alkaline hydrothermal conversion of glycerol using a 20 wt% Cu/NaY catalyst could selectively produce lactic acid (78 %) with glycerol conversions of 71 %, while a 20 %Ni-20 %Cu/NaY catalyst promoted the formation of gas-phase products such as H2, CO2, CO and CH4. Product yield was also considerably influenced by the molar ratio of NaOH/glycerol used, with better results obtained at higher NaOH concentration (up to 0.5 M). For the first time, a zeolite catalyst was reported for the CO2 APHT reaction. Jin et al. [45] synthesized Ru-REUSY catalysts by dealumination followed by liquid impregnation of Ru that facilitated CO2 conversion to FA using glycerol as a H-donor. With KHCO3 as the CO2 source, a 10 wt% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY catalyst (10 %Ru/REUSY dealuminated for 5 h) achieved the highest yields of FA and LA at 19.8 % and 6.1 % respectively. While zeolites possess properties that make them compelling for applications in APHT, there may exist considerable material limitations regarding their stability in alkaline reaction environments. In basic medium, framework silicon leaches from zeolites in a process called desilication [74,75]. This could also lead to leaching of metal from the catalyst, a phenomenon observed with metal oxide catalysts in the alkaline conditions used for glycerol APHT [49]. The result is lower stability of catalysts leading to deactivation. The feasibility of Ni/zeolite catalyst for promoting CO2-APHT in alkaline medium was therefore investigated in this work. The coupled CO2-APHT and the uncoupled alkaline hydrothermal conversion of glycerol under inert atmosphere (N2) were also investigated systematically to shed light on the role of the type and concentration of base employed and the effect of CO2 addition on the glycerol reacting system. Recycling tests were also performed to assess deactivation routes and stability of the Ni/zeolite catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A commercial NH4 +-ZSM-5 zeolite with Si/Al ratio of 11.5 supplied by Alfa Aesar was used. The zeolite was firstly modified with Na+ compensating cations via an ion-exchange procedure as described in [60]. For this, the zeolite was stirred at room temperature for 4 h using a 2 M NaNO3⋅6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≤99 %) aqueous solution at a volume of 4 mL/g of zeolite. After the ion-exchange, the suspension was filtered under vacuum, washed with deionised water and dried at 100 °C overnight in an oven. The ion-exchange procedure was repeated three times to ensure complete exchange of the ammonium by the sodium ions. Finally, the dried zeolite was calcined under dry air flow of 60 mL/min per g of zeolite at 500 °C for 6 h. The zeolite support was then loaded with 5 wt% Ni by incipient wetness impregnation, where an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (Acros, 99 %) with a volume of water close to that of the zeolite pores was added dropwise to the support. The catalyst was dried slowly by exposure to air for at least 2 days. This was followed by calcination at the same conditions described above. After Ni impregnation, the catalysts were reduced ex-situ in a furnace under 5 % H2 in N2 flow of 100 mL/min at 500 °C for 1 h. The temperature of reduction was selected based on the H2 -TPR results (see ESI Fig. 11). Reduced catalysts were stored in a vacuum desiccator prior to testing. Samples are denoted as Ni/NaZSM-5 (c) or Ni/NaZSM-5 (r) to indicate the 5 %Ni/ZSM-5 sample in the calcined or reduced state. An unsupported Ni0 catalyst was also prepared by calcining Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O in 60 mL/min per g of dry air flow at 500 °C for 6 h, then reducing in 50 mL/min flow of 5 % H2 in N2 at 500 °C for 1 h ex-situ before the reactions. 2.2 Characterisation Nitrogen physisorption measurements were carried out in a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 apparatus at −196 °C to determine the textural properties of the calcined zeolites. Without the addition of a base promoter, the extraction of the hydroxyl-hydrogen is limited and reforming or decomposition products such as propylene glycol, glycolic acid and CO2 are more prominent [76,77]. In line with this, carbonates, bicarbonates and hydroxides have all been used in the literature as bases [19,40,41,78]. Carbonates and bicarbonates have often been employed directly as both a basic promoter and a substitute for gaseous CO2 [14,18,19,35,40,41,44,79,80]. It was, therefore, pertinent to investigate the effectiveness of different types of bases for the APHT. The importance of the concentration of the base with regards to its catalytic effects was also investigated. To deepen the understanding of the complex reaction pathways that can come from glycerol transformations, the uncoupled glycerol dehydrogenation was also studied by performing reactions in inert atmosphere. Lastly, the impact of CO2 concentration on product distribution was investigated. 3.1.1 Effect of base type Fig. 1 shows the quantities of the main products obtained for the alkaline glycerol hydrothermal conversion for a variety of bases, when performing the reaction under inert atmosphere (N2) or with pure CO2. Blank runs without the addition of base were also performed for comparison, with negligible amounts of LA or FA being formed regardless of the reaction atmosphere. On the other hand, the formation of LA seems to be boosted by the presence of base, which was already expected as explained above. Even at low base concentrations, it is evident that both bicarbonate and carbonate outperformed hydroxide in the glycerol dehydrogenation into LA under inert atmosphere, with the carbonate being better than the bicarbonate (Fig. 1(a)). When comparing the performance of carbonate and bicarbonate, higher starting pH has been identified as a key factor for good APHT activity and the results presented here are consistent with literature [14,79]. However, the increase in pH does not have the same effect with the hydroxide, where LA product amount was lower than when using either carbonate or bicarbonate. The initial pH with hydroxide was 12.0 compared to 10.6 and 9.6 with carbonate and bicarbonate, respectively (ESI Fig. 1). Instead, the use of the hydroxide, even at higher pH, increased the production of secondary products produced from glycerol via reforming and dehydration, such as acetic acid and isopropanol (ESI Fig. 2), relative to glycerol dehydrogenation (ESI Table 1). Thus, the nature of the base also appears to play a role in the activation of specific reaction pathways. The addition of base also leads to an increase in the formation of FA, which is noticeable even under N2 atmosphere. As explained above, carbonates or bicarbonates as bases indirectly introduce CO2 into the reaction mixture which triggers the CO2 hydrogenation pathway into FA. However, FA production was also identified in the presence of NaOH. Indeed, FA formation has been reported in the literature as a byproduct in the alkaline hydrothermal conversion of glycerol to LA [34,81–83], according to Scheme 2. In NaOH, FA formation from glycerol has been attributed to two possible pathways. First is the degradation of a pyruvaldehyde intermediate, and to a lesser extent lactic acid, to formic and acetic acids [83]. Second is the retro-aldol condensation of a glyceraldehyde intermediate to formaldehyde and glycolaldehyde, followed by base-catalysed oxidation by water to FA and glycolic acid [82]. These reactions are plausible in the studied system as confirmed by the reduced LA, increased FA and increased relative amount of acetic acid observed when using the hydroxide instead of carbonates. Another possible route to FA, observed in the Ni catalysed aqueous phase reforming of glycerol, proceeds via a hydroxyacetone intermediate to form FA and acetic acid (Scheme 2) [84]. Indeed, in inert atmosphere, glycerol reforming appears to be a significant pathway with activity increasing with increasing pH. This is shown in ESI Table 2 where the dehydrogenation/reforming ratio decreases from 13.3 with NaHCO3 to 5.5 with NaOH. On the other hand, FA could also result from the hydrogenation of CO produced in-situ via glycerol reforming. In fact, under N2 atmosphere, lower CO amounts were generally measured for the bicarbonate, carbonate and hydroxide reactions when compared with a test with no base promoter (ESI Fig. 2). Other products observed were 1-hydroxyacetone, propylene glycol (PG) and iPrOH (ESI Fig. 2). These products arise from the sequential dehydration and transfer hydrogenation of glycerol ( Scheme 3). Glycerol hydrogenolysis to PG is a well-studied transformation [38,39]. The secondary transformation of glycerol to iPrOH has also already been acknowledged in literature [85,86]. PG content appears to be lower in the reaction with NaOH than in the presence of carbonates or bicarbonates. This may result from PG being transformed into iPrOH and acetone (ESI Fig. 2) and suggests that these reactions are favoured at higher pH (ESI Fig. 1). These C3 dehydration products were only detected in the product mixture under N2 atmosphere, which may further confirm that higher pH promotes the dehydrogenation pathways. In a CO2 atmosphere, there is, in general, a further increase in FA production (Fig. 1(b)). The increase in the FA could only be rationalised if (i) there was an increase in the secondary glycerol reforming transformations leading to the production of formic acid or (ii) the presence of CO2 in the reaction medium would lead to higher rates of CO2 hydrogenation reactions into formic acid. However, as can be seen from ESI Fig. 2, the amount of reforming products seems to be similar or smaller than those obtained in the tests performed under inert atmosphere, thus the presence of CO2 may result in a relative decrease in the reforming pathways. In addition, an increase in the amount of CO amongst the reforming products is observed in presence of CO2 and bases, when compared to the results under inert atmosphere, whilst the acetic acid production remains similar in both cases. This is accompanied by a decrease in the amount of H2, which suggests that the presence of CO2 does indeed lead to the activation of the CO2 hydrogenation route to FA. Based on thermodynamics, methanol (MeOH) would be a more favourable product of CO2 hydrogenation than FA (Eq. (1) and (2)). However, FA is normally the expected product in CO2-APHT with glycerol [13–16,18,19]. This may be due to the lower H2 availability required for conversion to FA along with the presence of water in the reaction medium, which is necessary to improve CO2 and base solubility and reduce mass transfer limitations that may arise because of the viscosity of glycerol. The H-donor may also play a role in the production of FA or methanol. For example, MeOH was observed as the CO2 hydrogenation product with EtOH as the H-donor [17], as opposed to iPrOH or glycerol which are the most commonly reported H-donors. The formation of MeOH was found to only be viable with linear terminal alcohols and not branched-chain alcohols due to the inability of branched-chain alcohols to undergo the necessary dehydrogenative coupling that produces the H2 needed to reduce CO2 to MeOH [78]. (1) CO 2 ( g ) + 3 H 2 ⇌ C H 3 O H ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) Δ H 298 K = − 49.4 kJ / mol (2) CO 2 ( aq ) + 3 H ( aq ) ⇌ CHOO H ( aq ) Δ G 298 K = − 4 kJ / mol Another interesting observation is that higher FA amounts seem to be obtained when using carbonate and hydroxide than in the presence of bicarbonate. Though, many authors have claimed that HCO3 – is the primary reactive species in both homogeneously and heterogeneously catalysed APHT, irrespective of whether CO2 or carbonate salts acting as the C-source [14,18,19,44,79,87]. However, other studies have also pointed out an increase in activity with increasing CO2 pressure (or amount) during low concentration (0.1 M) HCO3 – hydrogenation to FA, where the increased acidity caused by dissolution of CO2 was at the origin of the observed behaviour [88]. In fact, when considering aqueous systems of CO2, bicarbonate and carbonate, it is important to analyse the impact of pH on the dynamic equilibrium between these species in solution. At the final pH of the reactions, 6.1, 6.2 and 6.5 for the bicarbonate, hydroxide and carbonate respectively (ESI Fig. 1), physically absorbed CO2 and HCO3 – species dominate at ratios of 70:30, 50:50 and 60:40 of CO2:HCO3 –, respectively [89]. The increased APHT productivity with carbonate and hydroxide could then be attributed to the higher HCO3 – content in aqueous solution, with the carbonate presenting the highest HCO3 – concentration and so the highest activity. Surprisingly, LA formation was also enhanced after the addition of CO2 to the reaction medium. It is, in fact, suggested in the literature that decreasing the effective pH of reaction by increasing the CO2 pressure (or amount) leads to increased productivity towards LA [14]. It can be seen from ESI Fig. 1 that there is indeed a decrease in the pH of the medium when CO2 is present, which did not happen under inert atmosphere. Conversion estimated for glycerol and CO2 when using different types of bases are plotted in ESI Fig. 3. As expected, conversion of glycerol is generally low (< 10 %) due to the low base concentration. Unexpectedly, calculated CO2 conversions range between 15 (base free) and 25 % (NaOH). However, it is important to note that the CO2 disappearance from the reaction products can also be due to the CO2 dissolution. In base-free media, CO2 solubility in neat glycerol is significantly higher than CO2 solubility in water. Décultot et al. [90] reported a CO2 solubility in pure glycerol of 1.7 × 10−3 mole fraction at CO2 partial pressure of 180 kPa and 50 °C, while CO2 solubility in water at 50 °C and CO2 partial pressure of 101.325 kPa is 0.4 × 10−3 mole fraction [91]. In the 1:1 glycerol:water media studied in this work, this can then account for 10 % of the CO2 conversion and the modified conversion discounting the physically absorbed CO2 is shown in ESI Fig. 3 and ESI Table 3. The increase in CO2 conversion in the presence of the bases relates to the fact that CO2 solubility is dependent on pH in aqueous alkaline solutions, with the rate of dissolution increasing exponentially above pH 12 [89]. This is in alignment with the CO2 conversions observed (ESI Fig. 3), where conversion was 16 and 18 % in NaHCO3 (final pH 9.4) and Na2CO3 (final pH 10.3) respectively but jumped to 26 % in NaOH (final pH 11.7). Another source of CO2 consumption could be reactions with glycerol that were not studied herein. Such transformations may include glycerol carbonation or carbonylation to form products such as glycerol-carbonate or longer chain acids, aldehydes and ketones [92]. Higher CO2 solubility would likely increase glycerol transformation to these types of secondary products. To minimise the complex effects caused by carbonates and bicarbonates on the possible reaction pathways involving CO2, NaOH was selected as the base for all further investigations to better study the reaction mechanism. 3.1.2 Effect of base concentration Fig. 2(a) shows the results for uncoupled glycerol hydrothermal conversion as a function of the NaOH concentration. There is a steady increase in both LA and hydrogen formation with increasing NaOH concentration, which is consistent with literature [34,81,82]. This is not strange given that NaOH acts as a base catalyst for the glycerol transformation [31,32]. However, there is not the expected 1:1 LA:H2 molar ratio, which could be explained by H2 consumption by various hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions taking place as secondary transformations, as proposed earlier. Conversely, FA decreases as NaOH concentration increases, from its highest at 0.1 M with none detected at 2 M. It was previously hypothesized that under inert atmosphere FA may form from reforming along with acetic or glycolic acid (Scheme 2). However, no appreciable differences in acetic acid amounts measured were detected while glycolic acid content increased slightly with increasing NaOH concentrations (ESI Fig. 5). The decrease in FA could, possibly be associated with FA dehydrogenation into CO2 and H2 in the presence of higher concentrations of NaOH. It has been reported in literature that at low temperature, higher pH can stabilize formic acid as the formate salt hindering decomposition [14,93]. However, it is also known that hydroxide catalyses FA dehydrogenation [93], and at the relatively high temperature in this study, could have promoted FA dehydrogenation more effectively than a stabilizing effect of pH. At the same time, significant amounts of MeOH also appear between 0.5 and 2 M NaOH. One possible route to MeOH production could be the hydrogenation of in-situ generated CO/CO2 [94]. However, MeOH could also be formed via direct glycerol reforming to ethylene glycol (EG) ( Scheme 4) [76,84]. Usually, Ni supported catalysts are used in these systems, which are generally accepted as good glycerol reforming catalysts [48], but the reaction temperature employed in this study (225 °C) is within the operating conditions typically used in other studies (220–300 °C). The results, thus, suggest that the hydrothermal conditions along with the high concentrations of hydroxide could act as a mild catalyst for this reaction, which could be confirmed by the presence of EG amongst the reaction products (ESI Fig. 5). However, no EG is produced at 0.5 M, but only in the presence of 1 and 2 M NaOH. This associated with the fact that the amount of EG produced is much smaller than the amount of MeOH formed may indeed indicate that MeOH is formed from multiple routes (i.e. CO hydrogenation and direct reforming). Glycerol dehydration products, hydroxyacetone and iPrOH (ESI Fig. 5), seem to be promoted at lower NaOH concentration, while dehydration products shift from hydroxyacetone and iPrOH to PG at higher base concentrations. In general, there is an increase in total dehydration products with increasing NaOH concentration. However, the increase in dehydrogenation products is larger relative to the dehydration products (see dehydrogenation/dehydration ratio with increasing hydroxide concentration in ESI Table 2). Total reforming products also increase with increasing NaOH concentration. It is evident that the formation of LA, PG, iPrOH, and C2 products are base catalyzed and increasing NaOH/glycerol ratios improves reaction rates. Reforming pathways shift from acetic acid formation as the major pathway at low NaOH concentration to EG as the primary pathway at high concentrations. At high base concentrations, PG content is higher than acetic acid which may indicate competition in the transformation of the hydroxyacetone intermediate. Any additional reforming activity may then be shifted towards the EG pathway. Overall, reforming is the most dominant secondary transformation of glycerol (ESI Table 2). Fig. 2(b) shows the effect of increasing the concentration of NaOH for the coupled glycerol-CO2 APHT. The base concentration has a significant impact on the efficiency of the transfer hydrogenation of CO2 with glycerol, which is reflected by the clear improvement in FA formation in presence of CO2. Similarly, the much smaller amounts of H2 detected in the presence of CO2 than measured under N2, confirms the consumption of H2 by hydrogenation processes. This clearly indicates that CO2 hydrogenation via APHT is the dominant pathway for FA production under these conditions. It is also possible to note that FA amount (in the presence of CO2) increases up to 1 M NaOH, then decreases when using a 2 M basic solution. As discussed in the previous section, FA formation in the presence of CO2 is controlled by the higher availability of HCO3 – in solution due to pH. Similar to what was observed previously, final pH of the reaction medium was observed to be lower in CO2 than N2 at all base concentrations, ranging from 11.6 to 13.2 in N2 to 6.2–10.2 in CO2 (ESI Fig. 4), with the pH change decreasing with an increase in the concentration of base. Considering these values, CO2:HCO3 – ratios of 60:40, 15:85 and 2:98 were calculated at 0.1, 0.5 and 1 M NaOH respectively, indeed showing a higher HCO3 – amount at a base concentration of 1 M. However, a much smaller pH drop was observed at 2 M NaOH (final pH = 10.2, see ESI Fig. 4), which corresponds to a solution equilibrium containing only HCO3 – and CO3 2– species at a ratio of 35:65 HCO3 –:CO3 2– [89]. LA production is also generally higher in the presence of CO2 than in inert atmosphere (Fig. 2(a) vs (b)), owing to the decrease in the solution pH when CO2 is added as stated previously. However, while LA continuously increases with the addition of base under N2, a decrease in LA production is observed when increasing the amount of base from 1 to 2 M. This is consistent with the higher final pH value obtained when 2 M NaOH was used, when compared to the other base concentrations. In addition, whilst under inert atmosphere, MeOH starts being produced at 0.5 M NaOH, MeOH formation is only triggered at 1 M when CO2 is present, suggesting that a higher amount of base is needed to activate the glycerol to methanol reforming route. This could indicate a competition effect between the APHT and reforming in the presence of CO2, which could hinder MeOH formation from glycerol reforming. Indeed, up to 1 M base concentration, total glycerol reforming products are lower than in N2 (ESI Table 2). However, at 2 M NaOH, an inversion is observed, with MeOH content being higher in CO2 than N2. This could result from parallel transformations such as CO/CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. For example, higher CO production can be observed in the presence of CO2 (ESI Fig. 5), which can be attributed to CO2 activation or transformation via reverse water-gas shift (RWGS). While in alkaline environment up to 1 M in presence of CO2, CO can be detected amongst the secondary products (ESI Fig. 5), no CO was measured at 2 M, which could corroborate the higher CO transformation to MeOH at this base concentration. Glycolic acid showed a similar trend to LA (ESI Fig. 5), which could be due to the fact that both are derived from the glyceraldehyde intermediate (Scheme 1 and 2). If the limiting step for LA formation is the abstraction of the α-hydroxyl-hydrogen to form glyceraldehyde, this would have a knock-on effect on any further glyceraldehyde transformations including cleavage to glycolic acid. Moreover, dehydration activity towards PG or iPrOH was significantly lower across all base concentrations (ESI Fig. 5, ESI Table 2). In fact, there is a significant decrease in total secondary products for CO2 reactions compared to N2 (ESI Table 2). This can be attributed to the competition between glycerol dehydrogenation and the secondary transformations in the presence of CO2. Evolutions of glycerol and CO2 conversion under inert and CO2 atmospheres as a function of NaOH concentration are presented in Fig. 3. Regardless of the reaction atmosphere, there is a general increase in glycerol conversion with increasing base concentration, with values not exceeding 15 % conversion. With NaOH:glycerol ratios ranging from 0.015 at 0.1 M to 0.3 at 2 M, conversion of glycerol may be limited by the availability of base. Despite the partial suppression of the secondary glycerol transformations observed after addition of CO2, glycerol conversion only showed small variation when compared to the results under N2 atmosphere. This shows the higher relative dominance of the dehydrogenation reaction into LA (ESI Table 2) when CO2 is present. It is also important to note that LA, MeOH and additional byproducts only represent a fraction of the glycerol consumed (2–20 % in N2 and 1–28 % in CO2) (ESI Table 2), further suggesting unaccounted glycerol conversion. Trace amounts of succinic acid, for instance, were observed with 1 M NaOH. It is possible to produce succinic acid from glycerol through carbonylation with CO2. However, it is more typically produced via fermentation of glycerol [95]. This may indicate the possibility of producing longer chain organics from glycerol through carbonylation, cyclisation or oligomerisation under alkaline hydrothermal conditions, which could not be analysed in this study. Oligomers of glycerol can indeed be formed under similar conditions (glycerol:K2CO3 = 36 mol/mol, 250 °C) [96]. Furthermore, CO2 conversion increases steadily with increasing base concentration up to 1 M NaOH, where it plateaus. The variation in EG may shed some light onto this phenomenon, as EG appears at 0.5 M but then decreases dramatically at 1 M (ESI Fig. 5). The total reforming of glycerol via EG to CO2 could be the origin of this behaviour. With higher amounts of in-situ generated CO2 than at other base concentrations, the calculated "CO2 consumed" would decrease relative to the other reactions and would appear as a levelling off the CO2 conversion curve. Interestingly, a very significant rise of the calculated CO2 conversion from 40 % in 1 M to 100 % in 2 M NaOH is observed (no gas products were observed in 2 M NaOH reactions). As noted previously, the CO2 conversion is overestimated due to the dissolution of CO2 in the reaction medium. By extrapolating the results of the Wee group [97], CO2 solubility at 25 °C in 2 M NaOH solution is 79.8 g/L, which translates to an absorption capacity of 18 mmol CO2 in 2 M NaOH reaction medium. With average 30 mmol CO2 charged to the reactor, CO2 dissolution, thus, can account for approximately 60 % of the calculated conversion. Moreover, as stated previously, CO2 has a much higher solubility in glycerol than in water (mole fraction = 1.7 × 10−3 vs 0.359 × 10−3). There is some evidence that the CO2 absorption capacity of NaOH solutions may be further enhanced by the presence of glycerol [98–101]. In a study using a rotating packed bed, Chiang et al. [99] reported a 15 % increase in CO2 absorption efficiency from a 33 v/v% CO2 stream, when 26 wt% glycerol was added to a 0.5 M NaOH aqueous absorbent. However, with limited data on the absorption of CO2 in water-NaOH-glycerol ternary mixtures, the CO2 absorption capacity of the reaction media studied in this work was estimated as the total amount of CO2 absorption in NaOH aqueous solvent [97] plus that in neat glycerol [90]. By subtracting this estimated dissolved CO2 (ESI Table 3), solubility corrected CO2 conversions can then be reported and range from 12 % to 28 % (Fig. 3). What is most notable is the increasing impact on conversion that solubility has with increasing NaOH concentration. In fact, absorption of CO2 in the reaction medium accounts for 15 % of the experimental conversion at 0.1 M increasing to approximately 70 % at both 1 and 2 M. Based on the superior APHT performance at 1 M NaOH, this was used as base concentration in further investigations. 3.1.3 Effect of CO2 concentration Commonly, it is assumed that reactions involving CO2 utilisation will use pure CO2 as a feedstock. Although often overlooked, this is likely to require post-combustion carbon capture to separate CO2 from the flue gas. To explore whether such a step is necessary, it would be useful to explore CO2-APHT with a simulated flue gas to assess whether CO2 can be capture/utilise in a single pot. Herein, the first investigation into the adaptation of APHT for CO2 capture is reported by studying the process with a dilute CO2 mixture (5 v/v% CO2 in N2) that resembles the CO2 composition of the flue gas generated from the combustion of natural gas. These results are also key in discerning the role of CO2 addition to the glycerol hydrothermal reaction and identifying potential reaction pathways. Fig. 4(a) shows a comparison of reaction results with 5 % CO2 in N2 against either pure N2 or CO2 atmospheres in the absence of heterogeneous catalyst. There is a small increase in FA production with the use of dilute CO2, from 0.04 to 0.16 mmol when compared to reaction in N2, which further increases to 2.2 mmol for a pure CO2 atmosphere. This clearly shows an increase in the relative preponderance of the CO2 hydrogenation pathway to FA at increasing CO2 concentrations. This is further observed by the almost complete H2 consumption in pure CO2. Interestingly, despite this there is a small increase in H2 in the reaction medium when switching from the inert to the dilute CO2 atmosphere. This could be due to a reduction in the consumption of H2 by other secondary reactions, which can be hindered by the presence of CO2 as suggested previously. On the other hand, LA formation in the presence of dilute CO2 remains practically the same as in N2, only significantly enhancing when pure CO2 is fed which has been ascribed to the drop in pH as explained in the previous sections. Additionally, MeOH production experiences a small decrease when adding CO2 to the reaction medium. As indicated previously, MeOH can be formed via CO2 hydrogenation and/or glycerol reforming to EG (Scheme 4), with both routes involving the consumption of H2. In ESI Fig. 6, it is possible to see that there is a reduction in the EG production that grows with an increase in the CO2 concentration, meaning that this route for MeOH production seems to be progressively suppressed by the addition of CO2. Nevertheless, although EG production decreases to almost zero under pure CO2 atmosphere, MeOH found in the reaction mixture is comparable for N2 and dilute CO2 atmospheres. This could indicate that the CO2 hydrogenation route for MeOH is more dominant at higher CO2 concentrations, which is not surprising given that there is more CO2 and H2 available when pure CO2 is fed. In addition, only 0.08 mmol of other byproducts were detected in pure CO2 compared to 0.2 mmol under inert atmosphere. This also indicates that CO2 suppresses secondary glycerol transformations, such as glycerol reforming, while the direct APHT to LA and FA is favoured under alkaline hydrothermal conditions (ESI Table 2). However, glycerol conversion remained constant across the three reaction atmospheres (Fig. 4(b)), meaning that it is only the relative preponderance of the various glycerol transformations that changes. As discussed previously, glycerol conversion appears to be limited by the availability of the base under purely hydrothermal conditions. Concerning CO2 conversion, while CO2 conversion was 99 % with dilute CO2, total FA formation only accounts for 9 % of the consumed CO2. This indicates dissolution of CO2 into the reaction mixture as described previously in this paper. In this case, the total CO2 absorption capacity of the reaction medium is 5 times that of the CO2 charged to the reactor which equates to a solubility adjusted CO2 conversion of 0 % (ESI Table 3). This again emphasizes the complexity of rationalizing the independent CO2 pathways since FA formation must also comprise of some portion of the consumed CO2. 3.2 Heterogeneously catalysed APHT 3.2.1 Unsupported Ni catalyst versus Ni-supported zeolite catalyst To evaluate the beneficial effect of using a metal-supported zeolite catalyst instead of only a bulk metal catalyst or a basic zeolite, the transfer hydrogenation of CO2 with glycerol was firstly performed over the calcined NaZSM-5 zeolite and an unsupported Ni0 catalyst. Fig. 5 shows a comparison between the product distribution obtained over NaZSM-5, unsupported Ni0 and 5 %Ni/NaZSM-5. The NaZSM-5 zeolite shows a performance similar to that of the alkaline hydrothermal CO2-APHT (NaOH, Fig. 5), showing that the support alone is not responsible for any additional catalytic activity. On the other hand, the use of the unsupported Ni0 sample led to an increase in glycerol dehydrogenation, as reflected by the higher LA and H2 amounts in the reaction mixture as compared to the alkaline hydrothermal reaction. Glycerol dehydration and reforming were also enhanced in the presence of the unsupported Ni0 (decrease in dehydrogenation/reforming and dehydrogenation/dehydration ratios - ESI Table 4), which was much more dramatic for the dehydration route. Thus, the unsupported Ni0 seems to be effective in promoting glycerol transformation. This result is consistent with literature as a graphite supported Ni0 nanoparticle catalyst in NaOH environment gave excellent results in glycerol conversion to LA [102]. Garcia et al. [76] also demonstrated that Ni supported catalysts are required for effective glycerol reforming. However, the amount of FA in the reaction medium remained the same as for the alkaline hydrothermal reaction, showing that this catalyst does not appear to play a role in CO2 hydrogenation to FA. However, interestingly, a small amount of methane was noticed amongst the gas products (ESI Fig. 8), suggesting that the unsupported Ni0 catalyst leads to the occurrence of a small degree of CO2 methanation. Notably, LA and H2 production was vastly improved with the Ni-zeolite catalyst. When compared to the results for the unsupported Ni0 catalyst, the LA amount doubled, while H2 increased 6-fold. It is also noticeable that there was a small increase in FA when using the supported catalyst, showing that the supported catalyst is slightly more effective in promoting the CO2 hydrogenation to FA than the unsupported Ni0. Indeed, there is a shift in FA/LA ratio from 1 in uncatalyzed reaction to 0.6 with Ni0 and finally 0.4 with the supported catalyst (ESI Table 4). Methane content was also observed to double with the supported catalyst. Reasons for this will be discussed later. Total reforming products were also observed to increase from 0.5 mmol with the unsupported Ni0 to 0.9 mmol with the supported catalyst (ESI Fig. 8). This was also reflected in the increase of the reforming/dehydration ratio from 5.9 to 12.8 with Ni0 and supported catalyst, respectively (ESI Table 4). On the other hand, total glycerol dehydration remains approximately the same, even though there is a shift in the relative amounts of dehydration products (ESI Fig. 8). While PG formation is about half with the supported catalyst compared to unsupported (ESI Table 4), iPrOH production triples. Thus, the supported catalyst appears to drive the continued dehydration of glycerol towards the final product iPrOH (Scheme 3). Since the type of metal species is the same in both unsupported Ni0 and Ni-zeolite catalyst consisting of reduced Ni from NiO (as confirmed later in this work by XRD and UV-Vis spectroscopy, see Section 3.2.4), it is, thus, clear that the better performance of the Ni-zeolite catalyst is a result of a synergistic interaction between the nickel metal and the basic zeolite support. In fact, the presence of the support led to a reduction in the Ni particle size from 68 nm in the unsupported Ni0 (based on XRD data, ESI Fig. 13) to 7 nm in the Ni-zeolite catalyst after reduction (based on XRD data, Table 1). In addition, the presence of the basic zeolite support may give additional adsorption sites for the adsorption and activation of CO2 as previously reported in the literature [54]. The synergistic Ni-zeolite interaction promoted glycerol dehydrogenation and reforming, as well as CO2 hydrogenation to methane and FA, while inhibiting dehydration, when compared to unsupported Ni0. Finally, to investigate the effectiveness of the Ni-zeolite catalyst under base-free conditions, a run without the addition of NaOH was also carried out (Fig. 5). The harsh conditions of the alkaline environment can in fact introduce several challenges in cost and design of large-scale processing equipment. In addition, the basic medium could be undesirable for a zeolite supported catalyst since it could lead to the removal of Si from the zeolite framework (desilication), which could leave the possibility of reduced catalyst reusability as the alkaline environment could degrade the structure of the zeolite (this aspect is addressed later). After the success of Deng et al.[20], who effectively produced formaldehyde in a base-free CO2-APHT using a Ru/LDH catalyst, it was desirable to explore the 5 %Ni/NaZSM-5 catalyst in base-free conditions. Unfortunately, the overall activity of this catalyst was revealed to be much smaller in the absence of NaOH. There was only a very small liquid product content, with LA, FA and acetic acid being detected in the reaction medium in 0.2, 0.01 and 0.03 mmol, respectively. However, this was still significantly more LA and acetic acid than produced in the uncatalysed base-free test (0.005 and 0.007 mmol respectively) (Fig. 2, ESI Fig. 5). Thus, it is evident that the catalyst still has some minor independent activity towards glycerol dehydrogenation in the absence of base. Interestingly, this was the first time that CO2 in excess of that charged to the reactor was detected resulting in a negative CO2 conversion of −28.7 %. Therefore, under these conditions, total glycerol reforming to CO2 and H2 appeared to be the main active pathway, as appreciable amounts of H2 and this surplus CO2 were detected amongst the gas products. H2 content was significantly higher than that obtained under hydrothermal base-free and alkaline hydrothermal conditions without Ni/NaZSM-5. It is, therefore, still necessary for a base catalyst to be employed together with the supported catalyst at the tested conditions, to drive the reaction towards APHT and suppress glycerol reforming. 3.2.2 Ni-supported zeolite catalyst performance The Ni-zeolite catalyst was also tested under the alkaline hydrothermal conditions with increasing concentrations of CO2. The main products distributions under inert, dilute CO2 and pure CO2 atmospheres are shown in Fig. 6(a). Overall, there is a clear improvement in the formation of the main products when the Ni-supported zeolite catalyst is introduced to the reaction, when compared to the runs without catalyst (Fig. 4(a)). However, the relative distribution of the main products appears to be very similar in presence and absence of Ni/NaZSM-5, except for the pure CO2 atmosphere. In the presence of the zeolite catalyst, a pronounced decreased in the LA formation can be observed, which is especially evident under pure CO2 atmosphere. This is in fact contrary to what was seen in the absence of Ni/NaZSM-5 (Fig. 4(a)) and may suggest that CO2 and glycerol compete for the same active sites on the catalyst, resulting in a relative inhibition of the glycerol dehydrogenation to LA. In addition, while FA formation still increases with the CO2 addition, FA/LA ratio decreases from 1.0 in the absence of Ni/NaZSM-5–0.4 in the presence of the catalyst under pure CO2 (ESI Table 4). Surprisingly no increase in FA formation can be seen when compared to the results without catalyst with pure CO2 (Fig. 4(a)), despite the significant increase in H2 content which would allow for higher CO2 hydrogenation activity. This could be partially a result of the reduction in the relative preponderance of the reforming reaction to produce FA, such as conversion of glycerol to acetic acid (Scheme 2), in the presence of Ni/NaZSM-5 after addition of CO2. In fact, ESI Fig. 6 shows a decrease in acetic acid with the increase in the CO2 concentration, which is contrary to what was seen under alkaline hydrothermal reaction conditions without Ni/NaZSM-5. However, it could also indicate that Ni/NaZSM-5 is not very active in promoting the CO2 hydrogenation into FA at the studied temperature. It is possible, thus, to conclude that NaOH seems to be the key driving force behind CO2 transformation in APHT under these conditions. Additionally, a much higher decrease in the MeOH formation can be seen with the CO2 concentration in presence of the catalyst (Fig. 6 and ESI Table 4), which is accompanied by a significant reduction in EG (ESI Fig. 6). Thus, there is also a relative suppression of the glycerol reforming to EG and MeOH in the presence of Ni/NaZSM-5 when CO2 is added. Considering that per each mol of glycerol converted into LA one mol of H2 should be produced, equal amounts of LA and H2 should be expected if no other reactions consuming or producing H2 would take place. However, H2 found in the reaction mixture is higher than LA, which is the opposite to what was seen under alkaline hydrothermal conditions for pure CO2 without Ni/NaZSM-5 (Fig. 4(a)). It has just been discussed that the preponderance of some reactions consuming H2 decreased or did not increase significantly in the presence of the catalyst, such as glycerol reforming to EG and MeOH and CO2 hydrogenation to FA. However, this would not be enough to explain the difference in the number of moles of LA and H2 detected (6 and 9 mmol respectively). Therefore, one could hypothesise that this could be a result of complete glycerol reforming to CO2 and H2. In fact, a surplus of CO2 was measured under base-free conditions (Fig. 5), confirming that the Ni-zeolite catalyst may promote this reaction. In addition, this could also be corroborated by the decrease in CO2 conversion in dilute CO2 from 90 % in the uncatalyzed reaction to 80 % in the presence of Ni-zeolite catalyst (Figs. 4(b), 6(b)). As mentioned in the previous sections, CO2 formation leads to an apparent decrease in the CO2 conversion. In 100 % CO2, a decrease from 42 % to 39 % (or a decrease in solubility corrected conversions from 12 % to 7 %) is also observed. The relatively smaller change can be attributed to the higher starting CO2 concentration which would result in relatively smaller changes. This is accompanied by higher CO2 consumption to FA. In any case, the decrease may also prove the increased formation of in-situ CO2. Concerning secondary products (ESI Fig. 6), there was an overall decrease of their amounts in the reaction mixture in the presence of the Ni-zeolite catalyst with the CO2 addition. This is consistent with what was also observed for the alkaline hydrothermal without catalyst. It is also possible to see that glycerol secondary product formation via dehydration increased at a higher rate when exposed to the zeolite catalyst than the primary product (LA), regardless of the reaction atmosphere. This is reflected in the sizeable decrease in the dehydrogenation/dehydration ratios (ESI Table 4). On the other hand, there was little change in the relative preponderance between glycerol reforming and dehydrogenation between the reactions without Ni/NaZSM-5 and those reactions with, as confirmed by the similar dehydrogenation/reforming ratios in absence and presence of the zeolite catalyst (ESI Table 2, ESI Table 4). Succinic acid amounts also increased in comparison with the reaction without Ni/NaZSM-5 (ESI Fig. 6). As mentioned in the previous section, this is a result of glycerol carbonylation and oligomerisation. Indeed, GC-MS analysis of the reaction products indicated the presence of both cyclic ketones such as cyclopentanones and cyclohexanone, as well as etherification products such as diglycerol and dimethanol-dioxanes which are common products of glycerol transformation in the presence of zeolite catalysts [103,104]. These are shown in ESI Table 5 and in the proposed reaction network ( Scheme 5). Most remarkable is the presence of methane detected in the product streams with all reacting atmospheres. This has never been reported in glycerol-CO2 APHT studies. Indeed, methane is an accepted byproduct of Ni catalysed aqueous phase reforming under similar batch hydrothermal conditions [105–108]. On the other hand, Ni is a widely accepted catalyst for traditional CO2/CO methanation, albeit the ideal methanation operating conditions typically requiring much higher temperatures (400–500 °C) [109,110]. However, there have been reports in the literature suggesting the occurrence of a small degree of CO2 methanation during the depolymerisation of lignocellulosic biomass over Raney Ni catalysts, under hydrogen transfer conditions (200–250 °C) [10]. Moreover, zeolite supported Ni catalysts have shown incredible activity for methanation [50]. With these revelations in mind, the formation of CH4 in the APHT reaction is perfectly plausible given the combination of the easily accessible surface Ni species on the catalyst together with the high H2 content produced during the reaction. As compared to the results without Ni/NaZSM-5, the catalyst improved glycerol conversion in all reaction atmospheres (Fig. 6(b)). However, glycerol conversion decreased with increasing CO2 content, which did not happen in reactions without the catalyst. This confirms that the addition of CO2 has an overall inhibitory effect on the glycerol transformation when the zeolite catalyst is present. As mentioned before, this could be a result of an adsorption competition for the same active sites on the catalyst. CO2 conversion, on the other hand, seems to be consistent in the absence and presence of zeolite catalyst. Based on these results and the results under the varying reaction conditions discussed throughout the work, a reaction network for 5 %Ni/ZSM-5 catalysed CO2-APHT with NaOH promoter has been proposed in Scheme 5. While the formation of most products can be catalysed by NaOH, most are significantly boosted by Ni/NaZSM-5. This is true for both uncoupled glycerol hydrothermal conversion and coupled CO2-APHT. There were only a few notable exceptions that were identified. First is the formation of FA, which was boosted in N2 confirming the prominence of the glycerol reforming reaction but showed little improvement in 100 % CO2 because of catalyst competition effects. Second is MeOH which also was not boosted by the catalyst which could be another indicator of competitive effects by way of the suppression of reforming pathways or inhibition of CO2/CO hydrogenation. Last is the exceptional increase in hydroxyacetone in base-free conditions which proves the necessity of the base for driving both the desired dehydrogenation and hydrogenation reactions. By combining the pathways presented throughout this work, three main competitive pathways were identified. The first is the desired glycerol dehydrogenation to LA (denoted in red) which produces the required H2 for CO2 hydrogenation. Next is the reforming of glycerol (dark blue) to several C2, C1 and gaseous products. The third pathway is the dehydration of glycerol to a series of ketones and alcohols (green). The polymerisation of glycerol and carbonate to several cyclic and oligomeric species (pink) was also identified with the Ni/NaZSM-5, but further work is necessary to quantify the impact of these transformations. Last, the secondary transformation of CO2 to CH4 was also confirmed (light blue), catalysed by the Ni catalyst, and RWGS to CO was hypothesized. 3.2.3 Effect of reaction temperature The effect of reaction temperature on the CO2-APHT was also investigated for the 100 % CO2 reaction atmosphere, by increasing reaction temperature to 250 °C ( Fig. 7). A clear improvement in the main products formation is observed at elevated temperature. LA content increased by 48 %, while FA increased by an astounding 195 %. This resulted in the increase in FA/LA from 0.4 to 0.7 (ESI Table 4). This was accompanied by a nearly 50 % decrease in H2 content, which may be an indicator of an increased CO2 consumption towards FA. Increased glycerol reforming to FA (Scheme 2) could also be an attributing factor. However, a slight decrease in acetic acid along with an astounding increase in CO from 0.03 to 0.42 mmol was also observed at higher temperature (ESI Fig. 9), which may more be an indication of complete glycerol reforming. Nonetheless, the decrease in acetic acid, accompanied by the increase in FA, could suggest the occurrence of decomposition of acetic acid to form FA, CO and CO2 [111]. However, it has been observed in the literature that acetic acid does not easily decompose under APHT conditions similar to those studied in this work [10]. Moreover, the more than 4 mmol increase in FA cannot be accounted solely by this acetic acid decomposition. Therefore, the concomitant increase in FA and decrease in H2 content appears to suggest that the ability of the catalyst to perform the CO2 hydrogenation to FA is substantially improved with the temperature. On the other hand, only a slight increase in MeOH and other secondary glycerol byproducts was noticed with the increase in the temperature. This means that the overall relative preponderance of glycerol secondary transformation decreases with the temperature. Indeed, there was a notable increase in dehydrogenation/reforming and dehydrogenation/dehydration ratios with the temperature by 36 and 39 % (ESI Table 4), respectively. Furthermore, there was a 120 % increase in CO content, which may indicate a higher significance of the RWGS reaction converting CO2 into CO. The improved activity of the zeolite catalyst at higher temperature was also evident by an increase in glycerol conversion from 13 % to 21 % (Fig. 7(b)). On the other hand, the increase in the temperature leads to a decrease in the CO2 conversion by 5 %, which was unexpected given the drastic increase in FA production. Thus, this observation may suggest that surplus CO2 is being produced via glycerol reforming. While CO2 substantially inhibits formation of C2 products, it is clear that the in-situ production of CO2 via glycerol reforming is a significant consideration with Ni-based catalysts [76,84,92], as previously suggested. This observation is highlighted by the modified conversion values, which decrease from 7.2 % at 225 °C to 0.6 % at 250 °C, suggesting that at higher temperature there is net CO2 formation that offsets any consumed CO2. Overall, elevated temperature appears to be a key parameter in promoting not only overall catalytic activity but also the effectiveness of the APHT demonstrated by the remarkable improvement in FA/LA and dehydrogenation/reforming and dehydrogenation/dehydration ratios. Yields and TOF of the primary APHT products, LA, FA and H2, are reported in Fig. 8 and ESI Table 1, respectively. It is important to note that the yield of FA was calculated based on both glycerol and CO2 since it is evident, as discussed throughout this work, that it is likely produced from both reactants and the proportion of product formed from each reactant cannot be easily distinguished using the analysis methods employed in this work. Overall product yields are below 2 % without the Ni/NaZSM-5 catalyst and are significantly boosted by the addition of the catalyst. Highest LA yield was measured under inert atmosphere at 9.1 % (83 h−1 TOF), and while there is some inhibitory effect with the addition of CO2, it is possible to regulate the ratio of LA/FA by increasing reaction temperature, giving highest FA yield of 3.9 % (44 h−1 TOF). With the Ni/NaZSM-5 catalyst it is also interesting to see the remarkable yields of H2 produced at lower temperature (5.4 and 6.4 % in N2 and CO2 respectively) compared to the expected acids. It may be worthwhile to consider H2 as a third valuable product from the APHT. Furthermore, the activation of the CO2 hydrogenation is clear at higher temperature seen by the shift from high H2 yield to higher FA. In the CO2 APHT reaction, the highest TOFs of LA and FA of 62 h−1 and 44 h−1 were respectively achieved over Ni/NaZSM-5 at 250˚C. Compared to other recent works in the literature investigating CO2/carbonate APHT with glycerol, the TOFs achieved in this work show great promise for the further optimisation of the Ni/zeolite catalyst. Valekar et al. [22] achieved TOFs of 38 and 10 h−1 of LA and FA respectively over a Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Other works showed TOFs 5–10 times higher than those obtained herein [21,23], but it must be noted that these yields were achieved over optimised noble metal catalysts, while the present study importantly showcases the potential for employing zeolite supported transition metal catalysts with a view for catalyst optimisation in future work. 3.2.4 Catalyst deactivation and stability One of the major concerns with zeolite catalysts in alkaline reaction media could be deactivation by collapse of the zeolite structure. To assess any changes to the zeolite structure induced by the reaction, characterisation of the fresh and used catalysts was performed. The textural properties of the zeolite support and impregnated Ni-zeolites before and after reaction are shown in Table 1. As expected, the microporous volume (Vmicro) for the fresh ZSM-5 zeolite is much higher than the mesopores volume (Vmeso). A decrease in all textural parameters was observed with the incorporation of Ni. The external surface area (Sext) and mesopores volume were the most affected textural parameters with relative reductions of 16 and 23 % respectively, suggesting that Ni particles are mostly located on the outer surface of the zeolite and mesopores. The small decrease in Vmicro could be ascribed to some small degree of Ni deposition within the zeolite micropores or to the partial blockage of the micropores by the surface Ni particles. After reactions, there was an increase in Sext and Vmeso, which may indicate changes to the zeolite structure by desilication [112]. The increase in Sext could also be caused by removal of some surface Ni species. A reduction in the Vmicro was also observed for all spent catalysts when compared to the fresh sample, which could be due to coke accumulation during the reaction. This was most dramatic for the N2 225 °C sample which had an 93 % decrease in Vmicro. Such a drastic decrease could also be explained by deep desilication during the reaction, altering or collapsing the zeolite structure. Fig. 9 shows the XRD patterns for the NaZSM-5 support and Ni/NaZSM-5 samples before and after reaction. XRD patterns for the unsupported Ni0 before and after reaction can also be found in ESI Fig. 13 (a). Diffraction peaks characteristic of the MFI-type structure can be seen for all fresh zeolites [113]. After nickel incorporation there is a 12 % relative decrease in crystallinity of the zeolite, which may be due to a dilution effect of Ni addition. Diffraction peaks for NiO are seen for the calcined Ni/ZSM-5 sample at 43.3 and 62.8° 2θ, while the presence of metallic Ni0 was confirmed in the reduced sample with peaks appearing at 44.5° 2θ [114]. The phase of the unsupported Ni0 was confirmed by the presence of metallic Ni0 peaks at 44.6°, 51.9° and 76.4° 2θ. However, the characteristic MFI diffraction peaks were no longer present for the spent N2 225 °C catalyst, indicating an acute change in the zeolite structure after reaction under N2 atmosphere, which was corroborated by the dramatic changes observed from the N2 adsorption measurements (Table 1). The diffraction pattern for this spent sample was identified as Ni containing sodium aluminium silicate hydrate with formula Na(AlSi2O6)·H2O (ESI Table 6). This was expected given that under N2 atmosphere high basic pH is maintained throughout the reaction (ESI Fig. 7), which would facilitate the leaching of framework Si from the zeolite support via desilication [112]. On the other hand, this is not observed for the spent zeolite catalysts under CO2 where the MFI crystalline structure is still present regardless of the reaction temperature. This shows that desilication may not be a concern when CO2 is present, most likely because of the significant decrease in the pH during the reaction under these conditions (ESI Fig. 7). In fact, only a minor drop in relative crystallinity was observed when comparing the results before and after reaction under CO2 atmosphere conditions (Table 1). NiO and Ni0 crystallite sizes on the fresh Ni/NaZSM-5 and spent catalysts were calculated using the Scherrer equation and are shown in Table 1. Fresh Ni/NaZSM-5 showed small NiO size at 9 nm with similar Ni0 size after pre-reduction treatment. Ni0 crystallite sizes slightly increase after reaction indicating some degree of sintering of metallic species. Crystallite size of the unsupported Ni0 decreased from 68 nm in the fresh sample to 42 nm in the spent (ESI Fig. 13). The type of Ni species present on the calcined Ni/NaZSM-5 and unsupported Ni0 were also probed by UV-Vis spectra shown in ESI Fig. 13 (b). Bands around 300, 390, 429 and 725 nm can be attributed to NiO [115], while a broad band around 300–340 nm can be assigned to metallic Ni0 [116,117]. For the Ni/NaZSM-5, NiO is the main Ni species observed, with a primary band clearly visible around 300 nm. The zero-valence oxidation state of the unsupported Ni0 can also be observed with a broad band centred around 320 nm. These results confirm the presence of the Ni phases as observed by XRD analysis. TEM analysis was also performed to estimate the average Ni particle size of the fresh and spent zeolite catalysts with the results shown in Fig. 10 and Table 1. TEM shows the presence of heterogeneously distributed and relatively large Ni particles on the surface of the zeolite. Ni particle sizes measure from TEM are larger than the crystallite sizes calculated from XRD. At the magnification used, it was mainly surface species that could be observed. The difference between the TEM and XRD particle sizes could be explained by the inability to measure Ni particles within the zeolite pores which may have smaller size than surface species. A NiO particle size of 18 nm was determined by TEM for the fresh zeolite catalyst, the results being comparable to those estimated by XRD for the NiO crystal sizes. This confirms that NiO is located mainly on the zeolite surface, which is consistent with the results of the N2 physisorption. All spent catalysts show signs of erosion of the zeolite particles contours, which may be associated with the increase in the external surface area. The removal of some surface Ni particles is also visible for all spent catalysts, which is especially evident for the spent sample run under 100 % CO2 at 250 °C. Indeed, a slight decrease in Ni wt% from 4.4 to 4.1 is measured for the CO2 225 °C sample as analysed by ICP-OES (Table 1). Overall, an increase in the size of the Ni particles was noticed for all used samples, which can be associated with the occurrence of sintering of the Ni particles, as previously mentioned. Elemental analysis was performed by ICP-OES to determine the Si/Al ratio and Ni composition of the fresh and spent catalysts used in reaction under N2 and CO2 at 225 °C. The results (Table 1) show a 34 % relative decrease in Si/Al for the N2 225 °C sample. This confirms that desilication is indeed occurring for this sample and reinforces the observed changes in textural properties and loss of the original MFI crystallite structure seen by nitrogen physisorption and XRD. The increase in total Ni wt% could then result from a significant enough removal of the framework structure altering the overall composition of the catalyst. Remarkably there was no change in Si/Al in the CO2 225 °C sample which is promising when considering the stability of the support, namely in the milder conditions created with a CO2 reacting atmosphere. A slight reduction in the Ni content was observed for this sample when compared to the fresh catalyst, showing that Ni leaching from the catalyst is not very significant. Carbon deposition and residual compounds trapped in the pores of the spent catalysts were also investigated by TGA analysis. Data are shown in ESI Table 7 and ESI Fig. 14. Weight loss took place in two temperature regions, <200 °C and between 200 and 530 °C. Deposit removal below 200 °C is the loss of water from the zeolite pores. This accounts for the majority (70–86 wt%) of the weight loss for all samples except the used catalysts from the reaction under N2 atmosphere. Deposits removed at 200–530 °C can be attributed to soft coke (oligomeric species) in the zeolite meso and micropores [118]. The highest amount of coke was measured in the sample used under N2 showing 5.3 wt% coke. Next was the sample reacted in CO2 at 225 °C with 2.6 wt% coke deposits. Only 1.1 wt% was found on the sample in reaction with CO2 at 250 °C. None of the samples showed any carbonaceous deposition that required high temperatures for removal. These results follow the trends in secondary product formation observed. The reaction under N2 gave the highest amount of secondary products which, as previously discussed, could feasibly be polymerised or decomposed and trapped within the zeolite pores under the studied conditions. Though it is interesting that succinic acid was only measured in the reaction with CO2 at 225 °C, this may mean that heavier compounds are forming in the uncoupled reaction which were not analysed for in this work. Given the potential signs of deactivation observed above while analysing the results for the fresh and spent catalyst after one reaction run, a catalyst recycling test was performed to assess the stability and reusability of the catalyst, and results are shown in Fig. 11. After the 2 h reaction time, Ni/NaZSM-5 was filtered and washed with deionized water followed by ethanol until the filtrate ran clear and dried at 100˚C for 1 h. The catalyst was reduced in 5 %H2 in N2 mixture at 500 °C for 1 h to reactivate the catalyst prior to reuse. This treatment was performed to remove the coke deposits and re-reduce the Ni particles. Even though this has been done, it is evident that LA production decreased by 20 %, H2 by 24 %, and FA by 5 %. Thus, it seems that there was a greater effect of deactivation on glycerol dehydrogenation than on CO2 hydrogenation as seen by the increase in FA/LA from 0.36 to 0.43 (ESI Table 4). This higher effect on glycerol transformations was also evident by analysing the total glycerol reforming and dehydration product amounts, which decreased by 74 and 79 % respectively (ESI Fig. 15). This was accompanied by a small drop in glycerol conversion from 14 % to 12 %, as well as CO2 conversion from 39 % to 30 % or a decrease in modified conversion from 7 % to 4 %. Based on the characterisation of the spent catalyst after the first reaction run as discussed above (Table 1), the decrease in activity could be, thus, mainly related to sintering and partial removal of Ni. Indeed, glycerol transformations have been observed in the literature to be more affected by the size of the metal particles than CO2 hydrogenation [50,119]. After two reaction cycles, the structure of the zeolite still showed the typical MFI structure (Fig. 9), with only a 2 % decrease in relative crystallinity of the zeolite support (Table 1). There was only a small decrease in Vmicro of 5 % relative to the first cycle, which may indicate that a smaller amount of coke was formed in the second cycle. This was confirmed by the TGA results that showed only 1.7 wt% coke for the cycle 2 spent sample, as compared to 2.6 wt% in cycle 1. Moreover, similar amounts of coke were found in the recycled catalyst and the catalyst used at 250 °C (1.7 and 1.1 wt% respectively). Indeed, similar amounts of secondary products were measured in reaction at 250 °C as in the catalyst reuse tests, though higher temperature was shown to favour activity towards the primary APHT reaction which may inhibit oligomerisation reactions. Furthermore, no significant additional increase in the mesopores volume was observed after the second cycle of reaction, which may suggest that desilication from the first cycle was able to stabilize the zeolite against further erosion. Indeed, ZSM-5 desilication has been shown to improve the time-on-stream stability of the catalyst [113]. On the other hand, a further 52 % relative increase in the external surface of the zeolite catalyst was also noticed after the second reaction cycle (Table 1), which could be attributed to the further loss of surface Ni species. TEM of spent zeolite catalyst after cycle 2 shows in fact no further signs of erosion, but a smaller amount of Ni particles on the surface (Fig. 10), when compared to Fig. 10(c) for cycle 1. In addition, Ni particle size calculation based on TEM shows a decrease in the average size of the Ni particles on the zeolite after the second reaction cycle (Table 1), which could indicate that mostly the bigger particles, typically those with weaker interaction with the support, are leached during the reaction. If this is the case, one could expect a stabilisation of the Ni removal in subsequent runs. Based on these results, it seems there is a tendency for the causes leading to deactivation to stabilise after the second reaction cycle. However, further investigation of the zeolite behaviour when performing a higher number of reaction cycles is required to confirm this hypothesis. 4 Conclusion In this work, the transfer hydrogenation of CO2 using glycerol as H-donor into FA and LA was systematically investigated, by changing the type and concentration of base used and the reaction atmosphere. Moreover, the impact of the use of a Ni-supported zeolite, as heterogeneous catalyst, in the system, as opposed to the alkaline hydrothermal system without the catalyst, was also assessed. Amongst the different bases used in the alkaline hydrothermal system without Ni-zeolite, Na2CO3 and NaOH showed the highest FA and LA productions owing to the effect of pH on both CO2 (or HCO3 –) hydrogenation to FA and glycerol dehydrogenation to FA. Increasing the pH of the reaction medium (by increasing NaOH base concentration) was indeed observed to positively impact the efficiency of the transfer hydrogenation process between glycerol and CO2, with a maximum reached at 1 M. Under the investigated conditions, glycerol reforming and dehydration were also observed to take place, but to a lower extent. In addition, when comparing the reactions without and with the Ni-zeolite, it was clear that the Ni-supported zeolite was very effective in boosting LA and FA productions, and especially at higher reaction temperatures. Availability of hydrogen was also more remarkable in the presence of the Ni zeolite catalyst. In both systems with and without the Ni-zeolite, addition of CO2 to the reaction medium led to an enhancement of the CO2 hydrogenation to FA, while it slightly decreased the glycerol dehydrogenation to FA, due to a competition effect between CO2 and glycerol. This competition effect was, though, mainly responsible for the suppression of glycerol reforming and dehydration. Finally, stability tests of the Ni zeolite catalyst preliminarily showed that the zeolite structure is able to resist to the highly basic conditions, which was observed to be due to the pH drop in the presence of CO2. Thus, the transfer hydrogenation of CO2 using glycerol over Ni-supported zeolite catalysts has demonstrated significant potential for sustainable CO2 utilisation. The study confirmed that Ni zeolite catalysts could be effective for the aqueous phase hydrogen transfer of CO2, even under basic conditions. The successful conversion of CO2 to formic and lactic acids using bio-derived glycerol, even at low CO2 concentration, also emphasizes the feasibility of integrating this process into existing chemical and energy industries. Future work should focus on optimizing catalyst formulations and reaction conditions to enhance product yields. coredata.dc:description: The CO2 transfer hydrogenation with bio-glycerol over a Ni-zeolite was systematically studied to produce formic and lactic acids. The alkaline hydrothermal reactions without a catalyst and with Ni-zeolite heterogeneous catalyst were explored, focusing on the effects of base types and concentrations, reaction atmosphere and temperature. In alkaline hydrothermal reactions without catalyst, NaOH demonstrated superior performance at 1 M. A Ni/NaZSM-5 catalyst showed astounding performance giving 9.3 mol-L−1-g−1 lactic acid and 6.5 mol-L−1-g−1 formic acid at 250 °C after 2 h. Notably, the zeolite showed resistance to the highly basic conditions of the reaction medium. For the first time, CO2 conversion in aqueous phase was reported addressing the complexity of CO2 solubility. A reaction network was proposed including the diverse glycerol transformations not yet studied for this system. Overall, this study sheds light on the understanding of this complex reaction system and the potential of Ni-supported zeolites for sustainable CO2 utilisation.
